channel.title: Travel Blog: John and Amanda's EuroTrip

item.title: Welcome
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Welcome
Clemson, SC
Clemson, SC

Hi there,
Thanks for reading our blog! I am John Wilhite and my wife Amanda and I are about to embark on a six week backpacking tour of of Europe. Our plan is to travel cheap and experience as much authentic Europe as we can. We will be hitting the must see cities and also getting plenty of small town and local flavor, all while (hopefully) avoiding the tourist traps. Stay tuned for more entries as we go, but right now it's all about packing.

Because were on a tight budget, we're traveling the European way: Camping. We will probably stay in some hostels, but camping is the cheapest (and most interesting) way to see the continent. In the US, we think of camping as rustic settings far from cities, but pretty much all towns and cities in Europe have one or more campsites. They have many facilities including showers, laundry, bars, restaurants, bike rentals etc. Most are easily accessible by public transportation, which is great for us because we will be train hopping the whole trip.

For our trip, we are traveling as lightly as possible. We are carrying camping gear that most hostel backpackers wouldn't need, so we have to go light on everything else. We are splitting the tent between our packs, but we each have our own sleeping pad and Thermarest Sleep System. We both have 50 liter Osprey backpacks.

My packing list includes:
Tent Body, Poles, Stakes
2 Long Sleeve and 2 Short Sleeve Shirts
1 Pair of Pants
1 Pair of Shorts
3 Pairs of Underwear and Socks
Tanktop and Shorts as Pajamas
Rain Jacket
Packable Daypack
Toiletries and Camp Towel
Money Belt
Backpack Rain Cover
Teva Walking Shoes
Vibram FiveFingers for camp/shower shoes
Travel Cup and Utensil
Phone and Charger
Camelbak

Amanda is packing:
Tent Footprint and Rainfly
1 Long Sleeve and 2 Short Sleeve Shirts
2 Tanktops
1 Dress
1 Pair Convertible Pants
1 Pair Capri Pants
2 Scarves
3 Pairs of Underwear and 2 Bras
1 Pair of Socks (Her shoes are made to be worn w/o socks)
Toiletries and Camp Towel
Laundry Detergent and Clothesline
First Aid Kit
Travel Purse
Money Belt
Backpack Rain Cover
Jambu Walking Shoes
Chaco Flip Flops
Travel Cup and Utensil
Phone and Charger
Camera, Charger, Extra Battery and Extra Memory Card
Camelbak

item.title: It's Aliiiiive!!!
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
It's Aliiiiive!!!
Anderson, SC
Anderson, SC

Excerpt from The Birth of Frankenguide

"On a tepid moonlit night in May, in the far reaches of Oconee county, a mostly sane scientist began preparing his laboratory for his newest creation. One he had been planning for minutes, possibly even an hour. He took a brand new and unsuspecting guidebook, and he began to hack out the sections that he fancied. The gleaming blade of his XACTO knife cut through the pages like they were paper. He added parts from other guides and bound them together until the creation barely resembled its former self. Only after he had applied his own embellishment, the creator was able to marvel at his own ingenuity."


Guidebooks are great but for any trip, but when ounces and pack space are at a premium, carrying a full size Lonely Planet Western Europe guidebook can be a hassle. This is a situation where a kindle would be great (for downtime reading too), but since we don't have one, we have to make do. So I took our guidebook and cut out the pages I thought we might need. I easily omitted hundreds of pages (and ounces!) just for Greece and Spain and only kept the London, Paris, and Munich sections of the UK, France and Germany respectively.

I also printed out travel sections for Copenhagen and Prague from wiki travel since those cities weren't included. I added few pages from online articles about various hiking trails, directions to campsites, and whatever else I found to be interesting.

I punched holes in the pages and bound the book with some card stock and zip ties. Then I used some creative license to make a stencil and spray paint a fitting "Frankenguide" design on the outside.

item.title: We're Off!
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
We're Off!
Charlotte, NC
Charlotte, NC

After months of planning, it's finally time to leave. Right now, Amanda and I are killing a couple hours at the airport bar in Charlotte. We are both really excited, it hasn't seemed real until we actually got to the airport. I've been flying around the world for years, so I'm a good bit less nervous than Amanda. This is her first time out of the country, and only her second ever plane trip. It's commendable that that she has committed to a trip like this on her first ever time overseas. She is a trooper, and I know we will have a great time. The time change might be a little rough because we will land at 7am GMT in London, which will be like trying to wake up at 2am EST. It shouldn't be much of a problem for Amanda. After working night shift for 3 years, she's used to running on little to no sleep. We really appreciate all the well wishes we have gotten, and we look forward to updating everyone along the way!

item.title: London
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
London
London, United Kingdom
London, United Kingdom

First Step: London Well our plane was delayed 2 hours so we didn't make it to London until 9am.  We landed at London Gatwick which is about an hour south of the city.  While Gatwick is a bit more out of the way than Heathrow, Charlotte runs direct flights daily to Gatwick, so we saved a good bit of time and headaches by avoiding transfers.  We made it to our hostel about 1pm GMT and had to wait an hour or so to check in.  We splurged a bit staying here, but in London (the most expensive city on our trip) even the cheap hostels are not very cheap.  Our hostel is an old house and has a good bit of character. It even has a restaurant and bar downstairs. Even though we were tired from the flight and we lost some time from the delay, we managed to get out and walk Hyde Park and Piccadilly Square on our first day.  Unfortunately Buckingham Palace was closed for repairs.  On day two, we hit the famous landmarks: Tower of London, Tower Bridge, South Bank of the Thames, Parliament, Big Ben, Westminster Abbey, Harrod's and Soho.  We also went to King's Cross Train Station to get a picture of the famous 9 3/4 platform sign.  Amanda's sister Ellen is the biggest Harry Potter fan, and she would've killed us if we didn't get a picture for her.  We had been surviving on deli sandwiches, fruit and nuts until we went to have real fish and chips last night.  It has been raining all day today, and we have to catch the train to Paris at 5:30pm, but we went out to Wembley to see England's national stadium this morning.  Before we go to the train station, we are going to try to get up to see Emirates Stadium, home of Arsenal. Click here to see more pictures!

item.title: Paris
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Paris
Paris, France
Paris, France

Paris was our first camping spot. The campground was nice, but the weather was cold and rainy. Luckily our one season sleeping bags and complimentary airline blankets were warm enough. Paris itself was the same as when I was here 8 years ago: grand, historic, long lines and dirty. Maybe we were holding too high of standards because we had just come from London, where they are cleaning and updating for the Olympics. Mme. Parris would be glad to know that I can still speak a little French. I could ask some simple questions, but if the answer was too long or spoken to quickly, then I was lost. Luckily only a couple of people didn't speak English, and I could still get my point across. The first night we arrived, we just caught the last bus to the campground and had to set up the tent in the dark. The first full day we walked a good chunk of the city, from the Arc de Triomphe to the Louvre, past Notre Dame to the Latin Quarter. The highlight of Amanda's trip so far was walking around the Sephora store on the Champs-Élysées. Day two we saw the Eiffel Tower and its mile long lines, and the great panoramic views from Montmartre. It had seemed like a nice day that morning, so we washed our clothes and hung them up to dry, but it poured rain as soon as we got on the shuttle back to the campground. We had to pay €4 just to dry our clothes in the machine. The international crowd at the campground was very interesting. It seemed mostly like families and older couples, but there was a van of Australian girls near us who seemed like they were on a European party tour. Our last night we had fun drinking wine and watching the Germany vs Netherlands soccer match with a bunch of Germans and Dutch people. I think we were the only neutrals in the campground bar. When we were using one the campground computers (Internet is a precious commodity here, probably more so than public restrooms), we overheard an Italian family's discussion on how to google search for KFCs in Paris (we saw several). The youngest son's contribution was to repeatedly yell "Kentucky! Kentucky!". Now we're off to Belgium to escape the madness of the megacities. Hopefully even as we go north, it will warm up some (maybe the time difference here is 6 months and not 6 hours?).

item.title: Belgium
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Belgium
Brugge, Belgium
Brugge, Belgium

Belgium: the land of Beer, Chocolate, Waffles, and Fries. London is roughly the size of New York, Paris is close to Chicago, Bruges (Brugge in Dutch) is similar in size and feel to Charleston or Savannah. The coast is a few miles away, but the historic center of Brugge is medieval buildings, cobblestone streets, and canals. But before we could get to Brugge, we had a few difficulties along the way. Our last morning in Paris, we made it to the train station fairly early. After standing in the wrong line for 20 minutes, we were directed to the correct line, which had a 1 hour wait. When we got to the counter, we were told our railpasses did not cover the train to Brussels. We would have to pay full price for the high speed train leaving in 15 minutes, or wait and get on local trains with a several convoluted transfers. The two women at the counter didn't give us much choice and were barely understandable, so we reluctantly paid the €60 for the high speed train. When we got to Brussels, we knew there were a few sights we wanted to see. Amanda and I both have a good sense of direction and don't often get lost, but we found Belgium very confusing. We had no trouble with the London Underground or the Paris Metro, but the trains, subways, and buses in Belgium gave us a great amount of difficulty. We had to search the subway station in Brussels a good fifteen minutes before we found a line map. Then we entered the stop going the wrong direction and there was no way to change directions without going completely out (and wasting our ticket). In every other city, you enter and then pick the direction. Once inside the station, we had to walk to another line just to find a map. We were able make it to the center of town in a round about manner. We made to the Grand Place because we could see the spires from our station, but we couldn't find the cafe we had picked out for lunch (the guidebook only gave an address, street signs are sometimes hard to find as well). There were probably a dozen Italian and Greek places near the square, and the only Belgian places served just beer. Since our time in Brussels was limited and we were starving, we had Greek. After wandering the square for a while, we set off to look for the beer museum. The guide book map did not show the museum, and there were only some vague directions. After a little bit of searching with no luck, we decided that we would make sure we had a good map of each city that we tackled. We returned to the train station and boarded the next train to Brugge. We saw on the departures board that the train went to Ghent first, then on to Brugge (or so we thought). We were supposed to transfer trains in Ghent, but we ended up riding several stops too far. By the time we figured out what was going on, our car was deserted, and we got off at a stop called Bissegem (we looked it up later, it's almost in France) to try to get on a train going back the opposite direction. The Bissegem station consisted of a stretch of gravel and a bench on either side of the track. We couldn't make head or tail of the posted timetables, but we were able to make some sense of them after talking to nice old lady who spoke a little bit of English. We ended up waiting about 45 minutes to ride one stop back to Kortrjik, where we could catch the train to Brugge (No maps at any of these places). At the Kortrjik station, we waited another 45 minutes for the Brugge train. While we were waiting for the train, we talked to three Canadian girls, one who now lives in Brussels, who were going the same way. We decided it would be a good idea to follow them. We finally made it to Brugge about 3 hours later than we had intended, and surprisingly got on the right bus to the campground, Camping Memling. After we checked in and set up our tent, we were pretty hungry again. We walked back towards town and found that the bus had stopped running and everything around us was closed except for a fast food place called Quick. We reluctantly decided to go in, but soon found the Quick to be an oasis in an otherwise frustrating day. Though we never go to McDonald's or Burger King at home, the Quick's greasy burger and a fountain drinks (with ice!) were a welcome relief. The Quick also had free wifi so we hung out there a little bit; we checked emails and Facebook, and I posted the Paris entry. We are hoping the campground in Amsterdam has a computer so we can upload the pictures from Amanda's camera to Facebook. So far we have only posted London pictures. The historic center of Brugge was very nice. The outside edge is surrounded by a canal and modern suburbs. The inside consists of medieval buildings and churches, the streets are all cobblestone, and there are several smaller canals that weave through the center. Brugge is fairly touristy, but it's easy to dodge the crowds by avoiding a couple streets. We started by heading into the Markt, the main square of Brugge, which is dominated by the impressive belfry tower. We decided to try the famous Belgian fries we had heard so much about. At the Friterie, we ended up striking up a conversation with a family from Florida, after we heard them trying to figure out what was so special about the fries. They were plain fries, and the only interesting part was the array of sauces, ranging from gravy to curry ketchup. The oldest son is at FSU, and understandably not a Clemson fan. The most interesting place in Brugge was De Halve Maan brewery. We went on a tour that was capped off by some of the brewery's excellent internationally award winning beer. They had versions ranging from 6% to 11% alcohol (Patrick you would love this place). We also visited a bar that claimed to be the oldest in Brugge. The owners were documented all the way back to 1515. Inside we had some more beers from other parts of Belgium and talked to an older couple from Washington State and a local Belgian man named Jan. Jan has been coming to the bar for 40 years. He showed us a very old book written about the bar; it was kept outside, so it wasn't in great shape. We sampled the big 4 of Belgium: beer, chocolate, waffles, and fries. The only real disappointment was the fries. They weren't anything you couldn't get at the Bantam Chef. We decided that Brugge is our favorite stop so far, but we are really looking forward to Amsterdam.

item.title: Amsterdam
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Amsterdam
Amsterdam, Netherlands
Amsterdam, Netherlands

Amsterdam was the next stop on our list, and at 750,000 people or so, it is a fairly large city, but still more manageable than London and Paris. Amsterdam is famous for its liberal attitude towards drugs and prostitution, and even a walk through the Red Light District at 2 in the afternoon can be interesting. One thing you quickly learn in Amsterdam, a cafe is a bar/restaurant, but a coffee shop is where marijuana is sold. There is probably a coffee shop on every block. We left early from Brugge, because we were worried we might have another train fiasco like last time, but everything went well. We have started picking up a little Dutch, but the words we know almost much exclusively apply to transportation. We have taken enough trains and trams to learn that: volgende halte = next stop, bestemming = ending, Maandag = Monday, Vridag = Friday, Zaterdag = Saturday, Zondag = Sunday (We have no idea what the other days of the week are, all the timetables list Maandag-Vridag times). Many Dutch words sound similar to the English counterparts, even if the spelling if significantly different. Maybe that is why everyone in Amsterdam spoke perfect English. Often they would just start out speaking English to us and wouldn't bother with the Dutch. We arrived at the campground earlier than we were used to, and decided to just hang out at the campground restaurant/bar for the evening. The place started to fill up because of the Euro soccer tournament: Netherlands was playing Portugal, and Germany was playing Denmark. Pretty soon the place was packed with German and Dutch supporters. Netherlands ended up losing 2-1 to Portugal, an eliminating third loss for a team projected to be one of the favorites. The Dutch take their voetball very seriously, and were not at all pleased with their team's poor showing. Since Netherlands was eliminated, the next day we saw workers in the city pulling down the giant inflatable soccer balls and orange streamers that lined the streets. Our campground was more like what I expected from our European camping experience. There were virtually no tents in Paris, and Brugge was nice but very quiet. There was a much younger and rowdier vibe to Amsterdam, which is as attributable to the city as anything else. The campground didn't seem to have quiet hours and somewhat catered to those who were enjoying Amsterdam's "liberties". While the other campgrounds were mostly camper vans and families, Camping Zeeburg was young people and tents. We were directed to set up anywhere in a large field full of tents. Plus there were goats and chickens and donkeys... no idea why. The city of Amsterdam is fairly walkable, but we made use of the convenient tram system. The roads are set up so that there are two wide lanes for trams and buses, two narrow lanes outside that for cars, and outer narrow bike and scooter lanes. The car lanes were the least used; seems like everyone, young or old, rides a bike in Amsterdam. There several canals that circle the center of Amsterdam, and there are dozens of bridges over the canals. On every one of these bridges, there are dozens of bicycles chained or propped up. At first we thought they belonged to the people in the area, but we felt a few of the tires and figured out that they were abandoned. I guess when you get a new bike in Amsterdam, you just leave the old one wherever it happened to be. Amsterdam is a very relaxed place, and we spent a good bit of our time just sitting at cafes and watching the people walk/bike by. It seems like all the cafes are full around 3 in the afternoon with locals having a few beers (does anyone work here?). So we joined in, had a beer, and laughed at the bicycles narrowly dodging the tourists (we like to think we blend in a little bit better: we don't wear fanny packs, tie our jackets around our waist, or wear shirts that say "Amsterdam"). One of the more interesting foods we tried was Dutch Croquettes, or bitterballen. They are some sort of beef and gravy that is breaded and fried. I'm not sure exactly what was in them, but they were good! We also stopped a a lunch counter place and had a couple Dutch sandwiches. I had half sliced liver and half salted beef, and Amanda had smoked eel, both were very different but delicious. Though I'm a little ashamed to admit it, I was "hit" by a bike, but it was more like a graze. Funny thing though, it was in the campground and on the sidewalk, so I don't think I deserve any blame. A couple was renting bikes and getting the rundown on how to use them in the city, but they apparently weren't instructed on how to brake. These were fixed gear bikes with pedal brakes. After the girl bumped into me, the guy nearly ran into the back of her. So hopefully they learned how to brake before any real damage was done. Overall we really enjoyed Amsterdam. We had a lot of fun just enjoying the laid-back atmosphere of the city. I'm sure there's great deal more experiences to be had in Amsterdam, but I guess we will have to come back! Next up, night train to Copenhagen!

item.title: Copenhagen
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Copenhagen
Copenhagen, Denmark
Copenhagen, Denmark

Copenhagen is a city of contrasts: it is a historic city with some of the most modern buildings in the world, it is a major metropolitan area with a small city feel and it is a utilitarian port with artistic flair. Copenhagen has a population of over one million people, but the city center is so tight and organized, you would never know it. We thought we saw a lot of bikes in Amsterdam, but the people in Copenhagen live on their bikes. I read somewhere that 70% of the citizens ride a bike daily, but it seems like more. The increase of bikes and decrease of cars make the city center feel less congested and more enjoyable. With some apprehension, we reserved our beds in a 6 bed couchette on the night train to Copenhagen on our first day in Amsterdam. On the day of departure, we got lucky. We arrived at the station an hour early, and while waiting at the platform, we were told the train departure had been moved to Utrecht (30 minutes southeast). If we had not been early, we might not have made the train. We knew our cabin would be tiny, but it was still surprisingly small (the pictures don't do it justice). We were hoping that the transfer to Utrecht meant we might have less people in the cabin, but the other four people made it too. We got lucky with our bunk mates; there was a young Swiss couple, a young Australian guy, and a middle aged Australian lady (the two Aussies didn't know each other). The Swiss couple spoke perfect English, so we all talked for a few hours before sleeping. Everyone was nice, and they didn't seem like they would rummage through our stuff in the middle of the night. We spent a good bit of time with them watching Holland and Germany go by in the hallway outside our cabin. I guess nobody wanted to spend the entire 15 hours cooped up in a bunk that we couldn't even sit up in. When we got to Copenhagen, we took a regional train straight to our campground (this campground was the furthest from a city center yet - about 7km). The walk from the station to the campground took us through a park with a big historical house and the Aquarium of Denmark. The campground was situated in the middle of a beach park that got very crowded during the day. The area was a destination in itself, and we spent the rest of the day exploring the surrounding beach and parks. The campground was, by far, the nicest and most interesting so far (and the most expensive). The camping area was set up inside a former fort that protected Copenhagen's harbor from 1887 to 1934. The bunkers and cannons were still there. One of the bunkers was converted to the kitchen/lounge/bathrooms area, but was designed in an industrial modern way. The Danish are big on architecture and interior design, and we saw countless nice buildings and spaces. Ironically we were camping in a fort, but it was the least secure place we have been to yet. It seems like many people figured out that the shortest way to the beach was through the campground, so there was a lot of foot traffic by our tent during the day. But everything was fine. I talked to a few of the people, and the Danes seem very friendly. One thing we have noticed in Europe is increased efforts towards energy conservation. Utility costs are much higher over here and it shows. Most lights, especially in the bathrooms, are on a motion sensor. Some sinks in the US have the knobs you have to push down for the water to run, then cut off after 15 seconds or so. Here, the showers are either like that, or require coins for water. Either way, it annoys you into speeding up the process. In all honesty, the weather so far has been not been great. Every city has been colder than usual, but it seems like it clears up right after we leave. There has been a cold and rainy patch of weather moving at about our same speed and direction. So it was surprising that we had some sun when we arrived in Copenhagen. But it didn't last; the bad weather caught back up with us on our last day here, and it poured. Next up is Prague, a good ways south, so we should finally escape this stubborn weather system. Though I'm sure we will miss it when we are sweating in Italy.

item.title: Relatively Speaking
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Relatively Speaking
Copenhagen, Denmark
Copenhagen, Denmark

I always like to try to better understand things by comparing them to something familiar. After we got started, I was trying to visualize how far we were really going, and I found this map. I picked US cities and places that are roughly similar to our European itinerary. It is amazing how small Europe really is (or how big the US is). I thought it was interesting, so I decided to share it: London - Milwaukee Paris - Louisville Brugge - Cleveland Amsterdam - Detroit Copenhagen - Buffalo Prague - Baltimore Vienna - Wilmington Salzburg - Charlotte Switzerland - Knoxville Milan - Atlanta Florence - Jacksonville Rome - Orlando

item.title: Our sleep setup
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Our sleep setup
Copenhagen, Denmark
Copenhagen, Denmark

During the planning phase, we spent a good deal of time figuring out our sleeping setup. At first we thought we would just take sleeping bags, but our bags were bulkier and warmer than we needed, so we explored some other options. For as many nights are we are camping, a constrictive sleeping bag would be no fun. We decided to buy Therma-rest Tec Blankets and Therma-rest fitted sheets to go on our air mattresses. The blanket is like a thin sleeping bag but it doesn't include the bottom, so it is much lighter and packs smaller. The sheet fits over the air mattress and has several snaps along the edge. The blanket snaps onto the sheet to stay in place. The sheets and blankets can also snap to each other to form a connected mattress and blanket. It had been colder than we thought so far, and we ended up buying a 2pack of fleece blankets in Belgium. So far the setup has worked really well, and it is more like sleeping in a bed than regular camping.

item.title: Prague
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Prague
Prague, Czech Republic
Prague, Czech Republic

The jump from Copenhagen to Prague has to be the most drastic of any on our trip. While Copenhagen was clean, modern, efficient and expensive, Prague is expansive, historic, and a little rough around the edges. Probably the biggest difference is the residents. It wasn't uncommon to see men in Copenhagen wearing designer suits on bicycles. In Prague, it seemed like everyone picked out their outfits by being blindfolded at Goodwill. For the US equivalent, check out this website. The city of Prague is roughly the same size as Copenhagen but is more spread out and feels twice as large. Prague is also the first city we encountered any hills in since Paris, though I'm sure we will see plenty of "hills" in Austria and Switzerland. Prague is a very historic city, and remarkably well preserved considering all the wars and conflicts that have taken place in Central Europe. The city is somewhat of a bridge between Eastern and Western Europe, and the lingering effects of Communism can still be felt. In Copenhagen, when reserving our night train to Prague, we decided to get the 4 bed cabin. We got lucky because no one else booked the other two beds. We spread out, set up the table, played cards and ate dinner in comfort. When we got to Prague, we headed straight toward our hostel on the east end of town. We booked hostels in Prague and Vienna because we are only spending a couple days in each. We had been camping for almost two weeks, and sleeping indoors is a nice break. Our hostel was cleverly named the Czech Inn, and provided a much more social atmosphere than our last hostel in London. It seemed like 90% of the guests were native English speakers, mostly Americans, Canadians, Australians, and British, whereas the campgrounds are mostly mainland Europeans. Prague is also regarded as somewhat of a party city, and many of our roommates were taking advantage of the nightlife. While it might seem annoying to share a room with people coming and going at all hours, it worked surprisingly well. They left around the time we went to bed, and came back in when we were waking up. The most noticeable difference in Prague is that the dollar goes much, much further. We felt a little like the group in the movie Eurotrip, when they arrive in Eastern Europe and book a luxury hotel for a handful of change. In Copenhagen, a meal would cost around 150 Danish Kroners, and a Prague meal set us back 150 Czech Korunas. Though they sound the same, that's roughly $25 and $7.50, respectively. Not only were the meals a quarter the price, they were much heartier. It seems like Czech Republic is a meat and potatoes type country. We ate very well, and didn't have to worry about our budget. We were surprised at the first restaurant by the huge portions. We had grown accustomed to eating smaller meals throughout the day, but in Prague, it seems like every meal is a feast. At one restaurant, we thought we were ordering goulash, and at 180CZK ($9), it seemed like a good deal. But when they started bringing the food out, we realized it was a three course meal with potato soup, goulash, and gelato style ice cream for dessert. The Czech have definitely had the best food so far. The Czech Republic is well known for its beers. While not as famous or specialized as Belgium, the Czechs produce a wide variety of quality beers. Again the prices were great; We could sit down at a restaurant or beer garden and get a good pint for 25-30 CZK or $1.25 to $1.50. Needless to say, we sampled more beers here than anywhere else. I wanted to stay longer, but Amanda would be the first to tell you that she didn't like Prague initially. Coming from Denmark, it is quite a culture shock. Prague is a nice city, but it is rougher around the edges than any place we have been to so far. When we were out of the tourist districts, the sidewalks were uneven and rough, the was more graffiti, the people had worse haircuts and even worse taste in fashion. The public transport is functional, but not fancy. We bought passes, but never had to scan them or show them to anyone. The buildings are all either historic or remnants of the Communist era. I say this gives the city a different character, and Amanda agreed with me by the end of our stay. After some adjusting, she enjoyed Prague too. Prague has a surprising number of great sights and attractions to not be a mega city. We first visited the Old Town Square, which is the historic commercial nexus of the city. Now the streets that radiate out are all modern shopping streets, and it is a nice walking area. On the square is the famous Astronomical Clock. At every hour, a crowd gathers around, points their cameras upwards, and waits for the little show. We were on the square twice and managed to narrowly miss it. Our fellow hostelers informed us that we weren't missing much though. Apparently some elaborate cuckoo clock contraption pops out and winds around the clock. Prague Center is split by the Vltava river. Old Town Square is on the east bank, while Prague Castle and Lesser town are on the west bank. On our second day we explored the castle, which is supposedly the largest castle complex in the world. I believe it, because we could have probably spent all day there. Though it is less like what we think of as a castle, and more like a walled city on a hill The castle provides great panoramic views over the city, and has its own cathedral in the center. St. Vitus Cathedral is just as impressive as Notre Dame in my opinion, and the wait was 0 minutes vs Notre Dame's 2 hours (and we were there on a weekend). Below the castle and along the river is Lesser Town. Lesser town is the newer part of the city (it's only about 600 years old). There are many old shops, streets and churches here, but the most interesting sight is the Lennon Wall. Somewhat of a public memorial to John Lennon, the wall is a huge, ever-changing graffiti mural. Most of the "art" is dated, and all the dates I saw was within the past week. Prague was great, and I wish we had another day or so. We got a good feel for the city, and we will have to come back to see the rest. Next stop Vienna!

item.title: Vienna
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Vienna
Vienna, Austria
Vienna, Austria

Vienna was a little different than I expected. I thought of Vienna as somewhat of a quaint old city with the sounds of Mozart and operas ringing in the streets. While the city center is very historical, Vienna (Wien in German) is a modern bustling city. Vienna is a smaller version of London, both are historical and modern, with plenty of small parks and tree lined streets. A busy city with around 1.5 million people, Vienna is very relaxed and livable for its size. Vienna is Amanda's favorite city so far, and it is certainly up there on my list. We only had one full day here, but we felt like we saw a lot of what the city has to offer. The food was good, and still cheap compared to the rest of Europe. The city is not perfect though. The waiters are known for not being overly nice, but the people of Vienna seemed pretty friendly. The city allows smoking in restaurants and bars, which is almost extinct in the rest of Western Europe. Not only is it allowed, but pretty much everyone actually smokes in the restaurants. Both places we went to eat were very good and reasonably priced. Neither had menus in English though. Amanda and I are adventurous eaters, so we stuck to the meals of the day and rolled the dice. For lunch, she could tell she was ordering spinach, so I assumed it was a salad. Her meal ended up being some sort of puréed spinach with hashbrowns and an egg on top. She's says its the weirdest meal she's ever eaten, but she enjoyed it. I thought was getting noodles, but it turns out that knödel is a potato dumpling. My meal was much more normal, and very delicious, stuffed pork tenderloin with potato dumplings. At dinner, we figured out that hühner is chicken and puten is turkey. Amanda had the huhnerschnitzel and I had puten natur mit champignon sauce und reis (natural turkey with mushroom sauce and rice). We decided to trash our money belts in Vienna. Amanda had been just keeping hers in her purse, because it is too difficult to get money or cards out of it in public. I lost my debit card because it's just as easy to put the card between the money belt and my pants, as it is to put the card into the money belt pocket. I'm guessing it fell out of my pants leg in Copenhagen. I had a scare in Vienna because the snap came undone, and I thought the money belt (with my passport, credit cards and cash) was missing. Luckily my shorts held it in place on the side of my leg. They were only $4 on Amazon, so I guess we got what we paid for. We will just have to be careful with our pockets and her purse. We went on a long looping walk through the center of the city, and north to Praterstern and the Danube. In town, we saw more grand old historic buildings than we can remember. Praterstern is a historical theme park sitting in a park on the northeast side of town. The ferris wheel was built in 1897 and is one of the oldest in the world. All our literature made references to an Orson Welles scene from the "famous" movie The Third Man shot here. I've never heard of this movie, so I don't see how it could be that famous. We also saw the Danube from Donauinsel (Danube Island). The island is a several kilometer long skinny artificial island built in the middle of the Danube (or maybe they expanded the river around this part of land). The island is basically one long park, and is popular with bikers and joggers. We heard that there is a nude beach on either end, but the walk was too far to investigate. Vienna is a shopping city. There are tons of pedestrian streets with all the really expensive famous stores: Louis Vuitton, Gucci, Chanel, Tiffany and so on. On one of the less expensive streets, we found a cool graphic design and screen printing shop called Motmot (Design Website and Shop Website). We had some Tshirts printed, and talked to the owner while he was printing. He is originally from California and his girlfriend is from Italy, and they met while in college in California. She convinced him to move to Vienna and they opened up the shop. He said Vienna took some getting used to, but it's a good place to live. In one of the more touristy areas, we saw the most impressive street performers we seen so far. It is difficult to explain (check out the video at the bottom), but is basically an optical illusion to make one guy look like he is floating above the other. They must have some sort of elaborate hidden platform. They must've sat there, not moving, for over an hour, because we walked by several times. We didn't have a whole lot of time for Vienna, but we really enjoyed what we did see. We still have a couple weeks in German speaking countries, so maybe we will be able to read a menu by the time we are done. Now we are leaving the big city life and heading to a tiny town called Hallstatt in the Salzkammergut (Salt Mining) region of Austria.

item.title: Hallstatt
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Hallstatt
Hallstatt, Austria
Hallstatt, Austria

The village of Hallstatt, Austria is the epitome of a postcard town. Sandwiched between mountains and the lake, the town is situated on one narrow street, with a few cobbled lanes branching off. Every view is either a breathtaking mountain vista or picturesque little Austrian houses perched on the mountainside. All the houses have immaculate flower window boxes and tiny flower gardens. Amanda described Hallstatt as "the cutest town in the world," and she is probably right. Our last two stops were cities with well over a million people, but Hallstatt has less than a thousand permanent residents. I'm sure that number is much higher in the summer because of all the tourists. Hallstatt has no hotels, only gasthofs (guesthouses), so it seems to be more if a day trip for the tour buses. From 10am to 6pm the town swells with the elderly and Chinese/Japanese tourists (the two main groups who like to travel in packs and use tour bus groups). The Chinese love Hallstatt so much, they have cloned it! Click here for more info. We thought Hallstatt was small enough to not have too many tourists, but the crowds were pretty easy to avoid. We spent the middle of the day exploring the outskirts and surrounding attractions. Around dinner time, we felt like we had Hallstatt to ourselves. The two semifinal matches of the European Cup soccer tournament took place on the two nights we were there. There are only a couple of bars in town, and we watched the matches with locals. The second match was Germany vs Italy, and it became quickly apparent that Austrians were pulling for Italy. We watched the second half back at the campground with several Germans. I struck up a conversation with an older German couple, and even though they spoke very little English and I speak even less German, we had a pretty good conversation. They are from somewhere near Munich, and I told them I was from America östen and süden (east and south). They have some some sort of connection to Atlanta (family maybe?). I told them we were pulling for Deutschland because we are going to be in Munich on July 1st, the day of the final. They also asked if my father or grandfather was Deutsch, because of my hair and eyes. I told them it went further back than that, but I do have German heritage. The most notable activity we did in Hallstatt was a tour of the salt mines. Hallstatt's salt mine is way up the mountain above the city. We had to ride a funicular to get there. The mountains around Salzburg (Literally Salt City), are full of salt deposits. The salt mine at Hallstatt has been active for over 4000 years. The Hallstatt salt trade was so important in the prehistoric times that a period of the Bronze Age is called the Hallstatt era. The town and mine have been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site because of the history associated with Hallstatt. The tour even included wooden slides that the miners used to get to certain areas quicker (video at the bottom). One problem we had in Hallstatt and several other places, is the difficulty getting tap water with a meal. We are on a tight budget, so we can't afford to be spending €3 every meal on a Coke or bottle of mineral water. Most places will begrudgingly bring you a tiny glass of water if you ask, but some just refuse. I learned that leitungswasser means tap water to try and better get my point across, but it is still difficult. We always carry bottles if water around, so it's not a big deal to get no drink with a meal. We are not sure how anyone in Europe stays hydrated if they never drink water. Hallstatt was a great start to our break from cities. As we go further south, the less major cities, and the more small towns we are visiting. Munich, Florence, and Rome are the only big cities left on the itinerary. Salzburg, next up, is fairly large at 150k, but still a small and manageable city.

item.title: Salzburg
item.dc:creator: johnandamanda
item.content:encoded:
Salzburg
Salzburg, Austria
Salzburg, Austria

Salzburg is the city of Mozart and The Sound of Music. While the thought of Salzburg evokes romantic notions of classical music and stunning landscapes, the city was disappointing. It is ironic that the city so heavily promotes itself as the birthplace of Mozart, but Mozart himself couldn't wait to leave and moved to Vienna at 24. The cities other biggest draw, The Sound of Music tours, leave the city and venture out into the countryside. The best way we could think to describe the city is that someone came through and painted all the buildings various shades of beige and paved the city with asphalt and gravel. Half the stores in town sell the same brand of Mozart souvenirs, and the streets are lined with vendors selling other Austrian knickknacks. There are a couple nice parks, but the historic center has no green space. It didn't help that the temperature was around 35 degrees celsius during the day. I'm not sure exactly what that is in Fahrenheit, but it's in the 90s. Our campground was fairly nice and even had a pool! It was very nice to come back after sweating all day in town and jump in the pool. But the pool, like many other places in town closed at really odd times. It was open from 9am until noon, then closed until 2, then reopened until 7pm. I know they have siestas in Spain and Italy, but it seems a little ridiculous for a pool with no lifeguard in Austria. Salzburg definitely had the highest concentration of grocery stores of any city we've been to. That's good, because we make a lot of picnic meals from the grocery store, but it was difficult make it to a grocery store when it was open. All the SPARs (the chain of grocery stores that were everywhere) closed at 6pm on Saturday and were not open at all on Sunday. Most of the restaurants in Salzburg are either Italian or Greek, so we were surprised to come across a decent looking beer garden. We were beered out, but we did get a couple sausages that turned out to be the worst things we have eaten in a long time. There is a SPAR at the mall across from the train station, and the whole mall closed at 6. We got lucky and decided to check the SPAR in the train station (yes, there are literally two full size grocery stores of the same chain across the street from each other), and it stayed open til 11 and was open on Sundays! We were so tired of schnitzel and frankfurters that we bought a bunch of fruit and vegetables for salads and snacks. Normally I wait to write about our leaving train ride for the next cities entry, but this ride was so fitting of our time in Salzburg that it deserves to be here. We got up early to check out and catch the train to Munich. Ironically, we got on a RailJet, which is Austria's fastest and nicest train, but it was the most annoying hour and a half of the trip. Soon after we sat down, a family from somewhere in the Middle East sat down a couple rows in front of us. I'm not sure if they even knew how many kids they had, but I counted 7. They all appeared to be spaced roughly 9 months apart. The kids looked like the ones in the commercials trying to get you to send 15¢ a day to feed and clothe them. The father showed his ticket to Augsburg to most everyone around him, and everyone told him, "No this train only goes to Munich." He was told this repeatedly in German and English, but still decided to stay on the wrong train. I guess no one really corrected him, because they were at least going the right direction. The conductor checking tickets explained to him how to make the Augsburg connection, but I don't think he understood any of it. I wouldn't be surprised if they are in Zurich right now. The kids did not stop screaming/singing/making weird noises the whole ride. The mother made them all white bread and hotdog sandwiches, which they proceeded to get more on the floor than eat. The family was sharing a 2liter bottle of Coke. One of the kids apparently didn't like his sip because he spit it into the aisle of the train. He made it ok though by rubbing it into the carpet with his foot. After they were done with the Coke bottle, they felt that the appropriate method of disposal was to throw it on the floor. The one thing that really took the cake though, the mother changed the youngest babies' diaper in the train seat, without putting a blanket or towel or anything down. There were baby changing tables in the WC 15 feet away! After the conductor announced that we would be in Munich in 5 minutes, the mother found it a good time to walk aisle of the train while breast feeding the youngest baby. Well I guess nobody bats a thousand, and we certainly missed on Salzburg. The city probably would've been more enjoyable if weren't overshadowed by our recent memories of the baroque grandeur of Vienna and the spectacular mountains of Hallstatt. Oh well, we're looking forward to Munich!

Food
